p.s: The given text is an extract from Ayad Akhtar's 2012 play Disgraced, Scene 3.
The play is socially critical and deals with the diffusion of identity and the prejudices that specifically Muslims in America have to endure.
The extract can be identified as scene 3 of the play.
The scene takes place in the New York appartementapartment of Amir and Emily CapoorKapoor.
Previously to the scene their friends / business partners, the couple Jory and Isaac came to them for dinner.

During the dinner there already were tensions between the characters on race- / religion-based discussions but the situation finally escalates when Jory tells Amir that she was made partner in the law firm they both work for.
This is werewhere the given scene deployds.
Enraged from the discussion with Amir Jory enters the stage to Isaac and Emily kissing (cf. l. 18-20 p. 71).
Stopped from her plan of leaving Jory realises the meaning of the displayed moment of intimacy between her husband and Emily (cf. l. 21 p. 71).
When Amir aggresivelyaggressively enters (cf. l. 22 p. 71) the scenary, Jory agitates an interrogation on Isaac and Emily, accusing them of having an affair which they deny.
Jory hurt and disgusted is not convinced and refuses any form of physical or verbal affection from Isaac (cf. l. 14 p. 72).
The atmosphere is highly tense and aggressive.
Amir who had just been listening now turns to Jory accusing her of making the accusation against Isaac and Emily up to destroy his marriage on top of his career (cf. l. 18-19 p. 72).
Amir uses racist language such as the n-word and insults Jory profoundly (cf. l. 29 p. 72).
When Isaac joins in on the conflict to defend his wife, Jory snaps at him telling him not to touch her (cf. l. 33 p. 72).
Amir spits into Isaac's face resulting in Isaac indirectly calling him and animal on a religion based prejudice (cf. l. 1 p. 73).
Isaac leaves the appartementapartment.

Jory is also preparing to leave when she stops herself to tell Amir that a colleguecolleague of theirs - Mort - is retiring and that she will be the one to take over his caseload (cf. l. 6 p. 73) because of Amir's duplicitousness.
Jory then exits leaving Amir and Emily.
Amir who is obviously troubled by Jory's revelation.
She exits the stage to get coffee (cf. l. 20 p. 73).
When Emily returns from the kitchen the atmosphere is intense and it is quiet.
Amir then quietly confronts her about the affair with Isaac (cf. l. 27 p. 73) which Emily then admits to (cf. l. 31 p. 73).
Emily's justification are being stopped abruptly when Isaac who is in a torren rage hits her until she lies on the floor, her face bllodied (cf. l. 8 p. 74).
The scene is the escalation moment of the play.
The actions of each character are unravelled and a complete escalation develops.
